<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and now whatever will make them forget the drab, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">mudcoloured</del>, the dismal in their own lives. As the book</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">becomes more and more spun over with these influences,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the thing that the writer has to say becomes increasingly cumbered. It is only to be discovered in a flash of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">recognition Thus some say they that their beards</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">bristle when they come up on it; others that a thrill</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">runs down the nerves of the thigh. To disengage the song</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from its encumbrances becomes as time 
            <choice>
              <sic>gos</sic>
              <corr>goes</corr>
            </choice> on a task for</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the critic-- that specially equipped taster and trier</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">who was not yet in existence <del hand="ms">in print</del> when <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser">Spenser</rs> <add hand="ms" place="above">[illeg.]</add> emerged</l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>"For why, a Gods' name, may not we, as else the</l>

              </choice>, and measure</l>
            <l>our accents by the sound, reserving the quantity to the verse</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">paint, nor music; 
            <choice>

              <corr>but</corr>

            <choice>
              <sic>hisrian</sic>

            </choice> to see the present,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">must set it against an earlier age. To <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe">Spenser</rs>, the golden</l>
